title: Asking about the location of things (Part 2): Advanced location questions and directions

content.text: To express that something is 'near from' another object or place, we use the phrase قَرِيبٌ مِنْ (qarībun min). The preposition مِنْ (min) means 'from'. Remember that قَرِيبٌ (qarīb) is an adjective, so its form might change based on gender and number, but the common usage is shown here.

examples.english: The museum is near the hotel.
The station is near the market.

content.text: To express that something is 'far from' another object or place, we use بَعِيدٌ عَنْ (ba'īdun 'an). The preposition عَنْ ('an) means 'from' or 'about' in other contexts, but here it specifically means 'away from'. Similar to قَرِيبٌ, بَعِيدٌ (ba'īd) is an adjective and might change form.

examples.english: The library is far from the university.
The restaurant is far from the house.

content.text: When something is 'opposite' or 'across from' another, you can use مُقَابِلٌ لِـ (muqābilun li-). The particle لِـ (li-) acts as 'to' or 'for', but in this context, it completes the meaning of 'opposite to'. Alternatively, أَمَامَ (amāma) can also imply 'opposite' in certain contexts, though its primary meaning is 'in front of'. We will focus on مُقَابِلٌ لِـ for clarity here.

examples.english: The store is opposite the bank.
The apartment is across from the garden.

sentence.english: Is the bank near the hospital?

steps.context: Asking about proximity of two places.

sentence.english: The airport is far from the city.

steps.context: Stating that a place is distant.

sentence.english: The pharmacy is opposite the office.

steps.context: Describing a location relative to another.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'The school is far ___ the park.' (المدرسة بعيدة ___ الحديقة.)
steps.explanation: بَعِيدَةٌ is followed by عَنْ to mean 'far from'.

steps.question: How do you say 'The cafe is opposite the library'?

content.text: To say that something is 'between' two other things, we use the preposition بَيْنَ (bayna). This preposition is very straightforward and usually followed by the two nouns it connects, often in the genitive case (majrour).

examples.english: The cafe is between the bank and the library.
The book is between the pen and the notebook.

content.text: When giving directions, 'turn right' is اِتَّجِهْ يَمِينًا (Ittajih yamīnan) and 'turn left' is اِتَّجِهْ يَسَارًا (Ittajih yasāran). اِتَّجِهْ is the imperative form of the verb 'to turn/head towards'. يَمِينًا (right) and يَسَارًا (left) are adverbs of direction.

examples.english: Turn right at the traffic light.
Turn left after the store.

content.text: To tell someone to 'go straight', you use اِذْهَبْ مُبَاشَرَةً (Idhhab mubāsharatan). اِذْهَبْ is the imperative form of 'to go', and مُبَاشَرَةً means 'directly' or 'straight'.

examples.english: Go straight for five minutes.
Go straight then turn right.

sentence.english: The ATM is between the bank and the restaurant.

steps.context: Locating an object between two places.
Suggesting a turn at a specific point.

steps.question: Complete the direction: '___ right at the corner.' (___ يمينًا عند الزاوية.)
steps.explanation: اِتَّجِهْ is the correct verb for 'turn' in directions.

content.text: To guide someone to walk a certain distance until they arrive at a point, use سِرْ حَتَّى تَصِلَ إِلَى (Sir hattā taṣila ilā...). سِرْ is the imperative of 'to walk', حَتَّى means 'until', تَصِلَ is the subjunctive of 'to reach', and إِلَى means 'to'.

examples.english: Walk until you reach the roundabout.

examples.arabic: سِرْ حَتَّى تَصِلَ إِلَى نِهَايَةِ الشَّارِعِ.
examples.english: Walk until you reach the end of the street.
examples.transliteration: Sir hattā taṣila ilā nihāyati ash-shāri'i.

title.english: Asking for Directions: 'How can I get to...?'

content.text: The most common way to ask 'How can I get to...?' is كَيْفَ أَصِلُ إِلَى...؟ (Kayfa aṣilu ilā...?). كَيْفَ means 'how', أَصِلُ is 'I reach', and إِلَى means 'to'. This is a direct and polite way to inquire about directions.

examples.english: How can I get to the airport?
How can I get to the museum?

content.text: To ask 'Which way is...?' or 'In what direction is...?', you can use فِي أَيِّ اتِّجَاهٍ...؟ (Fī ayyi ittijāhin...?). فِي means 'in', أَيّ (ayyi) means 'which/any', and اتِّجَاهٍ (ittijāhin) means 'direction'. This phrase is useful when you know the place but not its general orientation.

examples.english: Which way is the bank located?
Which way is the school?

sentence.arabic: سِرْ حَتَّى تَصِلَ إِلَى الْمَسْجِدِ الْكَبِيرِ.
sentence.english: Walk until you reach the Grand Mosque.
sentence.transliteration: Sir hattā taṣila ilā al-masjidi al-kabīri.

sentence.arabic: عُذْراً، كَيْفَ أَصِلُ إِلَى الْمَكْتَبَةِ الْعَامَّةِ؟
sentence.english: Excuse me, how can I get to the public library?

steps.context: Politely asking for directions to a specific public place.

sentence.english: Which way is the train station?

steps.context: Asking for the general direction of a landmark.

steps.question: What does 'سِرْ حَتَّى تَصِلَ إِلَى' mean?
steps.explanation: سِرْ حَتَّى تَصِلَ إِلَى means 'Walk until you reach'.

steps.question: Complete the question: '___ I get to the hospital?' (___ أَصِلُ إِلَى الْمُسْتَشْفَى؟)
steps.explanation: كَيْفَ أَصِلُ إِلَى means 'How can I get to'.

steps.question: Which phrase asks 'Which way is the restaurant?'
steps.explanation: فِي أَيِّ اتِّجَاهٍ asks 'Which way / In what direction'.

title.english: Asking for Directions: 'Is it far from here?'
title.arabic: السؤال عن الاتجاهات: 'هل هو بعيد من هنا؟'

content.text: After asking for directions, you might want to know about the distance. You can ask 'Is it far from here?' using هَلْ هُوَ بَعِيدٌ مِنْ هُنَا؟ (Hal huwa ba'īdun min hunā?). هَلْ (Hal) is a question particle, هُوَ (huwa) means 'it' (masculine), بَعِيدٌ (ba'īdun) is 'far', and مِنْ هُنَا (min hunā) means 'from here'. For a feminine place, you would say هَلْ هِيَ بَعِيدَةٌ مِنْ هُنَا؟ (Hal hiya ba'īdatun min hunā?).

examples.english: Is the store far from here?
Is the library far from here?

content.text: To describe a location relative to a landmark, you can use بِجَانِبِ (bijānibi), which means 'next to' or 'beside'. This is a common way to specify a location more precisely. The noun following بِجَانِبِ will be in the genitive case.

examples.english: The museum is next to the old building.
The cafe is next to the theater.

content.text: To say 'behind' a landmark, use خَلْفَ (khalfa). This preposition, like many others, puts the following noun in the genitive case. It's essential for describing locations that are not immediately visible from the front.

examples.english: The school is behind the mosque.
The parking lot is behind the shopping center.

sentence.arabic: هَلْ مَحَطَّةُ الْحَافِلَاتِ بَعِيدَةٌ مِنْ هُنَا؟
sentence.english: Is the bus station far from here?
sentence.transliteration: Hal maḥaṭṭatu al-ḥāfilāti ba'īdatun min hunā?

steps.context: Asking about the distance of a bus station.

sentence.english: The hotel is next to the sports center.

steps.context: Describing the hotel's location using a nearby landmark.

sentence.arabic: يُمْكِنُكَ أَنْ تَجِدَ الْمَخْبَزَ خَلْفَ الْبَقَالَةِ.
sentence.english: You can find the bakery behind the grocery store.
sentence.transliteration: Yumkinuka an tajida al-makhbaza khalfa al-baqālati.

steps.question: How do you ask 'Is it far from here?' (for a masculine noun like a store)?
steps.explanation: هَلْ هُوَ بَعِيدٌ مِنْ هُنَا؟ is 'Is it far from here?' (masculine).

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'The park is ___ the hospital.' (الحديقة ___ الْمُسْتَشْفَى.) (Meaning 'next to')

title.english: Landmarks: 'At the corner of the street'

content.text: To describe something located 'at the corner of the street', use عِنْدَ زَاوِيَةِ الشَّارِعِ (ʿinda zāwiyati ash-shāri'i). عِنْدَ (ʿinda) means 'at' or 'near', زَاوِيَةِ (zāwiyati) means 'corner' (in genitive case), and الشَّارِعِ (ash-shāri'i) means 'the street' (also in genitive case).

examples.english: The cafe is at the corner of the street.

examples.arabic: يُوجَدُ مَتْجَرٌ كَبِيرٌ عِنْدَ زَاوِيَةِ الشَّارِعِ التَّالِي.
examples.english: There is a big store at the corner of the next street.
examples.transliteration: Yūjadu matjarun kabīrun 'inda zāwiyati ash-shāri'i at-tālī.

content.text: To give more specific turning instructions, you can say خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ الأَوَّلَ (Khudh al-mun'aṭafa al-awwala) for 'take the first turn' or خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ الثَّانِيَ (Khudh al-mun'aṭafa ath-thāniya) for 'take the second turn'. خُذْ is the imperative 'take', الْمُنْعَطَفَ (al-mun'aṭaf) is 'the turn', and الأَوَّلَ / الثَّانِيَ are 'the first' / 'the second'.

examples.english: Take the first turn on your right.

examples.arabic: بَعْدَ إِشَارَةِ الْمُرُورِ، خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ الثَّانِيَ عَلَى يَسَارِكَ.
examples.english: After the traffic light, take the second turn on your left.
examples.transliteration: Ba'da ishārati al-murūri, khudh al-mun'aṭafa ath-thāniya 'alā yasārika.

title.arabic: اتجاهات متقدمة: 'هو على يمينك / على يسارك'

content.text: After giving turns, you often need to specify which side the destination is on. Use هُوَ عَلَى يَمِينِكَ (Huwa 'alā yamīnika) for 'it's on your right' (masculine) or هُوَ عَلَى يَسَارِكَ (Huwa 'alā yasārika) for 'it's on your left' (masculine). For feminine, use هِيَ عَلَى يَمِينِكِ/كَا (Hiya 'alā yamīniki/ka). The suffix ـكَ (ka) is for masculine 'your', and ـكِ (ki) is for feminine 'your'.

examples.arabic: اِذْهَبْ مُبَاشَرَةً، وَسَتَجِدُ الْمَتْجَرَ عَلَى يَمِينِكَ.
examples.english: Go straight, and you will find the store on your right.
The library is on your left after the turn.

sentence.english: The pharmacy is at the corner of the next street.

steps.context: Describing a location at a street corner.

sentence.english: Take the first turn on your left.

sentence.arabic: الْمَطْعَمُ عَلَى يَمِينِكَ بَعْدَ الْمَبْنَى الْأَزْرَقِ.
sentence.english: The restaurant is on your right after the blue building.

steps.context: Indicating the side of the street where a place is located.

steps.question: Which phrase means 'at the corner of the street'?
steps.explanation: عِنْدَ زَاوِيَةِ الشَّارِعِ means 'at the corner of the street'.

steps.question: Complete the direction: 'Take the ___ turn.' (خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ ___)
steps.explanation: الأَوَّلَ means 'the first' and is used with الْمُنْعَطَفَ for 'first turn'.

steps.question: How do you say 'The market is on your left'?

title.english: Advanced Directions: 'You will find it next to...'

content.text: To assure someone they will find a place easily by a landmark, use سَتَجِدُهُ بِجَانِبِ... (Satajiduhu bijānibi...). سَتَجِدُهُ means 'you will find it' (the 'ه' (hu) pronoun refers to 'it' masculine). بِجَانِبِ means 'next to'. For a feminine object, it would be سَتَجِدُهَا بِجَانِبِ... (Satajiduhā bijānibi...).

examples.english: You will find the restaurant next to the bank.
You will find the library next to the university.

title.arabic: دمج الاتجاهات: مثال على مسار كامل

content.text: Let's combine some of the phrases we've learned to give a more complete set of directions. Mastering these combinations is key to navigating and giving clear instructions.

examples.arabic: اِذْهَبْ مُبَاشَرَةً، ثُمَّ خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ الْأَوَّلَ عَلَى يَمِينِكَ. سَتَجِدُهُ مُقَابِلَ الْمَسْجِدِ.
examples.english: Go straight, then take the first turn on your right. You will find it opposite the mosque.
examples.transliteration: Idhhab mubāsharatan, thumma khudh al-mun'aṭafa al-awwala 'alā yamīnika. Satajiduhu muqābila al-masjidi.

content.text: You've learned many advanced phrases for asking about and giving directions. Remember to practice these regularly. Pay attention to the correct prepositions and the gender of nouns when applicable. The more you practice, the more natural these phrases will become.

sentence.arabic: للعثور على المستشفى، سَتَجِدُهُ بِجَانِبِ البَرِيدِ.
sentence.english: To find the hospital, you will find it next to the post office.

steps.context: Guiding someone to a hospital using a landmark.

sentence.arabic: كيف أصل إلى المتحف؟ سر مباشرة ثم خذ المنعطف الثاني على يسارك، ستجده أمامك.
sentence.english: How can I get to the museum? Go straight then take the second turn on your left, you will find it in front of you.
sentence.transliteration: Kayfa aṣilu ilā al-matḥaf? Sir mubāsharatan thumma khudh al-mun'aṭafa ath-thānīya 'alā yasārika, satajiduhu amāmaka.

steps.context: A comprehensive example of asking and giving directions.

steps.question: Which phrase means 'You will find it next to the park' (for a masculine item like a restaurant)?
steps.explanation: سَتَجِدُهُ بِجَانِبِ الْحَدِيقَةِ means 'You will find it next to the park'.

steps.question: Complete the sentence: 'The cinema is ___ the main street.' (السينما ___ الشارع الرئيسي.) (Meaning 'at the corner of')
steps.explanation: عِنْدَ زَاوِيَةِ means 'at the corner of'.

steps.question: What is the imperative for 'Take the first turn'?
steps.explanation: خُذِ الْمُنْعَطَفَ الأَوَّلَ means 'Take the first turn'.
